bibl.title: Monthly Progress Report from Lunsford D. Fricks to the Surgeon General, February 5, 1924

div1.p: Fricks details his malaria investigation in the southern United States.

div1.head: Monthly Progress Report from Lunsford D. Fricks to the Surgeon General, February 5, 1924
div1.opener:
Mal
Report
Headquarters:
Field Investigations of Malaria,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Room 17, Court House,
Memphis, Tenn.
----
February 5, 1924.
Monthly Progress Report,
January 1923.
The Surgeon-General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Division of Scientific Research,
Washington, D.C.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to forward herewith monthly progress report
of malaria investigations conducted during the month of January,
1924, under the direction of this office.

Field Laboratory, Crowley, Louisiana: Personnel - Special Expert
M. A. Barber, Asst. San. Eng. W. H. W. Komp and Asst. San. Eng.
J. G. Foster.

Dr. Barber completed special observations of malaria in Central
American ports early in January, returning to Crowley January 12th.
Activities at Crowley Laboratory consisted of: (1) Preparation
of papers and reports; (2) Identification of mosquito specimens
collected in Central America; (3) Inspection of salt marsh Week's
Island, Louisiana, January 29th, where a few A. Crucians were
found flying; (4) Mosquitoes collected in image stage, A. quadrimac-
ulatus 11, A. crucians 20; adults and larvae much less numerous
than during January 1923; (5) 177 blood specimens examined for
malaria parasites; of 62 smears collected locally 3 were found
positive.

Memphis Laboratory: Personnel - A.A. Surgeon Wm. A. Eraues, Micros-
copists Ethel Barrier and Retha Kitchens.

633 blood smears examined for malaria parasites. 72 smears col-
lected locally showed 4 positives; 203 smears from Tunica, Miss.
showed 35 P. falc., 4 P. vivax; 115 smears from Stuttgart, Ark.,
showed 8 P. falc., 10 P. vivax; 100 smears from Greenwood, Miss.
showed 3 P. falc., 2 P. vivax; 143 smears from Gulfport, Miss.
showed 7 P. falc.

Field Laboratory, Savannah, Ga.: Personnel - Technical Assistant
Bruce Mayne.

Mr. Mayne conducted a study of the winter habits of Anopheles in
this region to determine primarily in what stage and under what
conditions Anopheles over winter. Anopheline larvae were frequent-
ly found in bottom mud of ice-covered streams, no pupae encountered.
Monthly Progress Report
-2-
February 5, 1924.
under these conditions until last week of January, in every in-
stance these proved to be A. crucians. Not more than six adult
mosquitoes were found hibernating after careful search in fav-
orable localities. Mr. Mayne concludes, that for Che tham Coun-
ty Georgia in all probability Anopheles overwinter commonly in
the aquatic forms and not in the imago stage. Two specimens of
adult A. punctpennis were collected in January, the first en-
countered since July 1923. 34 blood specimens collected locally
were examined, all negative for malaria parasites.

Epidemiological Studies of Malaria: Personnel - Asst. Surgeon K.F.
Maxcy.

During the month a spot map was prepared, showing locations from
which positive malaria slides were sent in for examination by pub-
lic health laboratories in the state: Case reports of malaria in
Alabama for 1923 were tabulated according to counties and nearest
town, this data is being put on a spot map. Dr. Maxcy spent con-
siderable time in the preparation of a paper dealing with the
“Epidemiological Principles Affecting the distribution of Malar-
ia in the southern United States”.

Impounded Waters in Relation to Malaria: Epidemiologist T.H.D.
Griffitts and Asst. San. Eng. E. H. Gage.

Dr. Griffitts engaged in making mosquito surveys in and around
Tampa, Florida. No impounded water studies made in Alabama.

Inspections of ponds in Aiken County South Carolina by Mr. Gage
yielded moderate number of anopheline larvae, all sizes, and one
pupa; non-anopheline larvae were found in shallow ponds, but no
anopheline larvae noted there; water temperature at time of col-
lections varied between 45 and 50 degrees F.; the pupa collected
emerged, after being kept at room temperature for 48 hours, as a
female A. crucians.

Major Drainage in Relation to Malaria: Personnel - Assoc. San.
Eng. A. W. Fuchs.

Mr. Fucha made analysis of data obtained by malaria survey of
school children and from census card distribution, covering res-
idents of McKinney Lake Drainage District in Tunica County, Miss.:
224 blood smears collected from school children showed 17.2% posi-
tive; spleen rate of same children 18.7% positive; spleen and
blood combined 29% positive; history rate for 1923 46% positive;
the blood rate among white children was 7.4% positive, among
colored children 19.2%.

Rural Malaria Investigations: Personnel - Asst. San. Eng. J. C.
Carter, A.A. Surgeon C.P. Coogle, Assoc. San. Eng. L.M. Fisher,
Asst. San. Eng. H.N. Old, Asst. San. Eng. F.R. Shaw, Surgeon L.L.
Williams.
Monthly Progress Report
February 5, 1924.

Mr. Carter (Alabama): Mr. Carter visited Lowndes, Butler, Conceuh,
Monroe, Escambia, Clark and Baldwin Counties for the purpose of se-
lecting these localities which have serious malaria problems, and
outlining a program of malaria control for each.

Mr. Old (Georgia): Mr. Old spent the first half of the month search-
ing for hibernating anopheline mosquitoes, only three adults found,
2 A. punctipennis and 1 A. crucians; last half of the month spent
in making malaria school surveys with Dr. Coogle.

Mr. Shaw (Louisiana): Mr. Shaw gave malaria talks and showed parish
malaria exhibit to children of six rural schools in Tangipahoa Par-
ish; study made of winter habits of Anopheles in this locality; Hib-
ernating imagoes of A. Punctipennis, A. quadrimaculatus and A.
crucians found in out-houses, A. quadrimaculatus most abundant, 6 to
1 of each of the others; half grown Anopheles larvae found active
on January 11th, following five days of unusually cold weather, dur-
ing which the thermometer reached 10 degrees F. on January 6th. Pre-
liminary survey made of St. Mary's Parish.

Mr. Fisher (South Carolina): Study of malaria distribution in
South Carolina continued by means of school census cards; malaria
census cards mailed to all school children in six counties; the
data collected from Charleston County indicates that from a pop-
ulation of 3.987, 14.4% had malaria in 1923; this same method in-
dicated 15% history index for Orangeburg County.

L. L. Williams (Virginia): Study of control of mosquito production
by means of raising and lowering water level alone being conducted
by Dr. Williams in five ponds in James City County.

Dr. Google continued malaria school surveys in Florida, Georgia
and South Carolina; 1243 school children examined for enlarged
spleens, Florida 626, Georgia 573, South Carolina 44; 696 blood
smears collected for examination, Florida 104, Georgia 548, South
Carolina 44.

Conferences and Inspections: No malaria conferences nor inspections
made from headquarters during January. Mr. LePrince and the Medi-
cal Officer in Charge engaged in preparing program for 1924 malaria
field investigations and conducting routine administrative duties.

Expenditures: During the month approximately $3,821.77 was expend-
ed from the Malaria Allotment in connection with field investiga-
tions of malaria.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, L. D. Fricks, Surgeon,
Medical Officer in Charge.
